Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2013 08:03PM sundermom wrote: I, too, experienced extreme tightness post radiation. My PS went in and released a "severe" capsular contracture because it was so painful and causing problems with the use of my dominant arm. To make it ten times worse I was in DisneyWorld with my kids when this went down. Long story, short - I had to totally re-do reconstruction and we used fat grafting the second go around. The difference was amazing! My poor, radiated skin looks totally normal now. I highly recommend fat grafting!

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2011 03:11PM - edited Mar 25, 2011 03:13PM by sundermom Day #2 of DD Taxol #2 So far Taxol #2 has been much kinder to my tummy.  That could have to do with the fact I'm now on Prilosec daily and Caraphate before each meal.  I got my Neulasta shot at 9AM this morning, so I'm bracing for the inevitable bone pains.  So far, so good though - usually the pains start about 6hrs. after the shot and I'm at 9 hours now and pain-free!  My boys are scheduled to play in a baseball tournament this weekend and it's supposed to be freezing here in Ohio.  The thought of bone pain coupled with sitting in the freezing cold don't really appeal to me, but I try to never miss a game.  I got to watch one of my DSs play a lead in his school musical last night.  He's nine and memorized countless lines and dance steps.  I was amazed and so proud to watch him perform.  One of my DDs will celebrate her 6th birthday this weekend, so I had fun shopping for her birthday persents this afternoon. We're officially on Spring Break!  On Monday DH and I will drive all five kids to Michigan to stay at "Camp Gramma & Papa" and then we'll fly out Tuesday morning for our trip to Jamaica.  I found out yesterday that I'll have an appointment with a RO sometime between April 7th and April 21st.  There is new research suggesting that radiation after BMX can benefit women with the following characteristics: under 40, intermediate/high grade, LVI, T1 or T2 and estrogen negative.  I have 4 out of the 5 criteria so I may very well be looking a radiation now.  In the study, which was small (only 500 women) there was a 30% reduction in a recurrence and a 50% decrease in mortality.  It may be something to ask about. I also found out that I will be taking Tamoxifin even though my cycles have stopped.  I will take it for two years and then we'll re-evaluate to see if this is real menopause or chemical menopause.  Thanks Proud_Mom for commenting when I brought this up in an earlier post. Tammy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2011 05:20PM - edited Apr 3, 2011 05:22PM by sundermom I'm back!!! Jamaica was wonderful - 85 and sunny every day we were there.  I felt great the whole time (even the TEs weren't as annoying as usual) and food tasted good again.  I drank enough alcohol to make up for the fact I hadn't had a drop since New Year's Eve.  We got a couples massage, spent LOTS of time on the beach and took "naps" every afternoon.  I feel like I got my batteries re-charged and I am ready take on the last two Taxols head-on and knock this chemo crap out. I have tx#7 on Thursday.  It will be the next to last one :) Mary Meg - Thanks for the shout out.  I'm no superwoman.  I do a lot of praying for strength, courage and wisdom.  I have an amazing husband and he definitely carries the brunt of the load on the homefront. Melissa - My appetite on AC was horrible.  I lived on mashed potatoes, bananas and orange Gatorade.  I would also take a tentative first bite and then let my stomach decide if it was something I was going to be able to tolerate.  I took a ton of nausea meds on Days 2-4.  I use both Ativan and Ambien for sleep.  I fall asleep in about 20 minutes and I sleep like a baby, which has never been the case for me before taking medication.  ProudMom_Wife - I, too, am feeling encouraged as I approach the finish line.  My last tx will be on April 21st.  JulieH - I'm with you on the sweets and diet soda.  I'm trying to view it as a blessing in that I probably ate/drank too much of this stuff to begin with.  christine47 - I have experienced some wicked hot flashes.  They seem to come more frequently after a treatment.  They are definitely worse at night; however, they are brief so I'm not ready to ask for meds yet.  Taxol #2 before my trip went as predicted.  No nausea.  Bone pain on Days 2-5 - ugh!  The bone pain did seem milder this round, but it was still there.  My IV infiltrated and I got a nasty red, swollen rash on my hand, but it seems to be on the mend now.  It's back to school for us tomorrow :( Tammy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 25, 2011 03:06PM sundermom wrote: Wow!  There's been a lot of action in the past few days.  I'm still dealing with the annoying bone pain this round which should subside tomorrow. My hands and feet started to feel tingly this round, so I'm very thankful it was my last treatment.   Melissa - I still get completely nauseous when I see red liquid (Gatorade, Koolaide, etc.) and I'm 8 weeks out from my last AC.  My poor kids can have NOTHING red to drink :)  LOL  Also, ice makes me sick to my stomach because I had to chew so much of it during AC.  My DH was chomping down on some ice the other day and I had to leave the room.   Bdavis & Christine - I, too, have found myself thinking about recurrence and mets.  My RO assured me that chemo, Tamoxifen (I was 98%+ estrogen receptive) and rads in combination with the BMX put me in the less than 10% relapse rate and I was staged (IIB) higher than both of you :)  So . . . my thoughts . . . 90% chance this will NEVER happen again.  There aren't too many things in life with odds like that.  My grandmother is a 25 year BC survivor and she didn't have the benefit of all the research and treatments we have now.  Stay positive, ladies! I'm counting the days until my exchange surgery (15 to go!) and trying to read all I can about rads.  I'm almost more nervous about this than chemo.  Everybody knows you're supposed to feel sick with chemo, but everyone's experience with rads seems so different - some get horrible skin issues while others have none. Tammy

Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 09:05AM sundermom wrote: It's too cold for baseball!!!  I sat for 7 hours in 35 degree weather yesterday.  Again, I say, it's too cold for baseball.  It was nice to watch my boys play, but every muscle in my body ached after we got home last night.  I'm feeling better today and packing is lifting my spirits. christine47 - Women that are in menopause are usually prescribed something called an AI, as opposed to Tamox.  My grandmother (25+ year BC survivior) took Tamox even though she was menopausal because that was the only medication available at that time. Posts.Content: Mar 27, 2011 09:48AM sundermom wrote: christine47 - My onc said he always uses the status of your cycles prior to chemo to determine whether it will be Tamox or AI.  Chemo can screw up your cycles (to the point you don't have them at all - like me), but you're not actually in menopause, so taking an AI wouldn't work correctly.  He says we will reassess the Tamox vs. AI dicussion in two years with bloodwork to test my follicle stimulating hormone (FSH) level, but he thinks my cycles will resume since I'm only 37.  For those of us that are ER+ it's important we get the right drug since it's our most powerful protection against a recurrence.

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2011 04:10PM sundermom wrote: DD Taxol #3 Day #2 Yesterday, my next to last chemo, went fine.  I finally got bossy and asked that a nurse start the IV first and draw the necessary labs off of that instead of getting stuck twice.  Why is this not standard of care for those of us without ports?   The body aches are already starting and the taste buds that were so alive on vacation are now dull again.  I know this will only last until Monday, but it sucks everytime nonetheless.   I have an appointment for a radiation consult on Thursday.  It will be interesting to see what the RO says since I've had a BMX and an AND on the affected side.  I'm not sure what there is left to radiate, but like all of you I am willing to do anything to avoid going down this road again. If I do end up qualifying for rads then my exchange surgery will happen ASAP.  Goodbye TEs!!!!   13 days until last chemo!!!! Tammy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 04:07PM sundermom wrote: This time tomorrow I will be D-O-N-E with chemo!!!  I ordered some chocolate covered strawberries for my ONC and the nurses in the infusion room.  I made a card with pictures of my five little ones.  They save a lot of people's lives in that center each day, but being a mother of young children (10, 9, 7, 6 and 3) I want them to know just how special that truly is for me. There was a time when I was first dx that I let my mind go to bad places (not seeing kids' birthdays, graduations, wedding or grandchildren) and the staff there is so positive your mind just can't stay there for long.     My BFF, DH and around 30 other friends are joining us at a local Mexican restaurant tomorrow night for BAMs (big a** margaritas) and spicy food.  I can't believe I've made it - 16 weeks, 8 DD treatments, including the red devil.  I missed 8 days of work (infusion days) and not a single athletic event for one of my kiddos.  I am blessed - truly blessed. I'm expecting the exchange surgery (May 10th) and radiation to be a walk in the park :) Tammy

Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2011 09:20AM sundermom wrote: Sherry - My PS was adamant about having the reconstruction prior to the radiation.  He said the tissue doesn't stretch as well after its been treated with radiation.  I don't know what kind of recon you are contemplating, but I had a BMX with TEs and it took about 12 weeks to get to the size I wanted, but I went VERY slowly with the fills during expansion - only 30cc per side per week.  bdavis - I am a scarf gal all of the time, so that's my plan for Jamaica.  We are hoping to do some water activities so I'm a little worried about my scarf blowing off, but at least I'll be surrounded by strangers!   Taxol #1 has been kind to me!  The "good" days have been great and the "bad" days were nothing compared to before. I go for #2 on Thursday, so hopefully it's just as easy.  I'll also get the final decision about rads at my appt.   I just finished making our family vacation reservations for Dinsey World in October 2011.  For a split second I asked myself, "Should I make these reservations?"  As I inch closer the finish treatment finish line (not counting 60 bottles of Tamox) I find myself thinking more about the future. I've decided I can't let my fear of recurrence affect what I hope are the next 50+ years (I'm 37) of my life.  My grandmother assures me that the farther out you get from this experience the less you think/worry about it.  She's 85 years old and a 25+ year BC survivor.   I'm headed out to watch my little guys play some baseball today.  The season has started so that means I'll be go, go, go until July 4th.  Fingers crossed I don't lose the scarf with a big gust of wind!  I can just see my son's face out at shortstop if his mom's scarf blows across the field.  LOL Tammy

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2011 04:27PM sundermom wrote: Day 2 of dd AC and the lesson learned today was don't skip the nausea meds!  I was napped right through my 3PM dose of Zofran and by 4PM I was a mess.  Luckly, it must kick in pretty quickly because I was feeling better by 5:30PM.  I'll NEVER let that happen again.  I got the Neulasta shot today and my second expansion.  I am sore and stiff.  This reminds me of the few first days after my BMS.  Sleeping has been an issue for me too the past couple of days.  I already take an Ativan, and Ambien and a Vocidan at bedtime LOL so hopefully as some point my body will just let sleep happen.  I, too, am concerned about mouth sores.  I sucked on ice chips during treatment yesterday and have been using the baking soda, salt, water mixture that my oncologist suggested.  Take Care Tammy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 05:15PM sundermom wrote: So . . .many of us are approaching the chemo finish line and some lucky ladies the end of treatment line (excluding Tamox), too!  I don't think anything any of us did anything to cause BC, but it is certainly a life-changing experience.  I'm curious if anyone has adopted any lifestyle changes as result of the dx.  I've read several good books since being dx, including: AntiCancer: A New Way of Life, The Breast Cancer Warrior and Love, Medicine and Miracles.  As a result I've been trying to do the following each day: drink 4-5 cups of green tea get 5-7 servings of fruits and veggies, including 1 cup of cruciferous veggies (i.e. broccoli,cauliflower) 30 minutes of exercise (this is the toughest for me - not enough hours in the day) take Vitamin D supplements ( I chew one Vitactiv with lunch and one with dinner) be more aware of consuming nutrient-empty sugar (I would describe myself as a candy-addict before chemo.  Now it tastes like crap!) no red meat (This isn't a huge issue for me, because I only ate it like twice a year before) I don't know if it's the chemo, the lifestyle changes or a combination of both, but I've lost 20 pounds and I look and feel better (most days) than I have since HS.  How about you ladies? Tammy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Apr 20, 2011 04:51PM - edited Apr 20, 2011 04:52PM by sundermom I take both Ambien and Ativan every night.  I fall asleep within 30 minutes and stay asleep all night aside from the occasional hot flash.  I have Xanax that I carry in my purse for those teary times that can hit at the most inconvenient times.  I don't like to take meds either, but sleep is when we heal.  In fact one of the many books I've read touted the benefits of taking 4mg of supplemental Melatonin (a natural sleep aide) for BC survivors.  I think the further out we get from this experience, the better we'll sleep. Until then, thanks goodness for drugs!  I have 17 pills bottles, my kindergarten daughter counted and sorted them (some have pink lids and some have white lids) a few weeks ago.  Thankfully, most of them as "as needed". LOL Tammy

Posts.Content: May 25, 2011 08:11PM sundermom wrote: Melissa - I had a BMX in December before chemo.  I think you'll find the surgery much easier than the chemo.  I, too, found the drains to be the most annoying part of the whole process.  I got the first two out 7 days after surgery and the other two out 2 weeks post-op.  I got very creative in finding places to stick my drain bulbs when I went out in public :)  I lived in sweatpants, a loose cami and a zip-up sweatshirt for about 3 weeks.  I also slept in a recliner for about a month, but I had the TE placed at the time of the initial surgery so you'll probably recoup faster. I've started rads now which is so much different than chemo.  I find myself getting more annoyed by it actually because it's every stinking day.  I know it's been less than 7 months since my dx and I just have 30 days of treatment left, but I'm so ready to be done with this crap!  Tammy

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 03:21PM sundermom wrote: Hi All!  I just wanted to chime in on the switch from AC to Taxol.  I would definitely says that Taxol treated my differently.  No nausea. No dizziness.  No extreme fatigue.  No eye issues.  I did experience a fair amount of joint pain that seemed to last longer than when I got the Neulasta shot alone.  Nothing over the top, but it made me feel stiff and sore for Days 2-4.  I also experienced some GI issues (a gnawing pain right near the belly button and what can only be described as a spastic colon) this round.  My onc attributes this to the nice, big doses of decadron.  He's calling in some meds right now, actually :)  bdavis - I hope you have a wonderful trip.  I leave for Jamaica in 14 days and am so excited!  I, too, am nervous about feeling well enough to travel.  I tried to plan around what are typically "good" days for me, but the switch to Taxol has thrown a wrench into that!  On Tamoxifin . . . I think I've shared before that my periods have completely stopped.  We're going on 3 months now.  My onc mentioned that I have to have my levels tested because I may be in permanent menopuase and have to take an AI instead.  I'm 37.  I know Tamox has been the gold standard and it makes me nervous to think I won't be able to take it.  Anyone else in this boat??? Tammy

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2011 05:43PM sundermom wrote: Melissa - Don't be scared of AC :)  It just different.  The nausea was more of a factor for me, but I started alternating Zofran and Phenergen every 3 hours around the clock on Days 2 and 3 and that kept things manageable.  Since those meds cause constipation I also took 1 Senokot at bedtime each night.   I did feel like my whole body was dehydrated.  The treatments I did a better job of staying hydrated and eating then the easier the SEs were. I stocked up on mashed potatoes and Ramen noodles - bland, bland, bland!!!  As far as work (I think I mentioned that I'm an elementary principal) my treatments were on Thursdays and I was always able to go back to work on Monday.  Just let yourself sleep.   You'll make it through!!!! Tammy

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2011 05:03PM sundermom wrote: Lumpectomy vs. Mastectomy is a very personal decision.  People tend to feel very strongly one way or the other.  I am 37.  I have 5 great kids and had the chance to breastfeed and we don't want any more, so I opted for the BMX even though initial scans showed only a primary tumor on the right.  However, the final pathology from the surgery showed a small satellite mass in the same best, so I was very happy with my decision.  I had very large breasts (DD) and a very small frame (4 feet 11 inches 120 pounds), so I also looked forward to the opportunity to downsize.  Finally, I choose the BMX for cosmetic reasons.  I wanted as much symmetry as possible and the PS assured me that I would get better symmetry if he reconstructed both sides as opposed to trying to to match a recon to an existing breast.  I also had the AND and don't have any numbness,  I did right after surgery, but all feeling has returned to my underarm area.  I can also say that I am regaining sensation in some portions of both breasts.  The TEs are annoying, but you get used to them.  I think Melissa is absolutely right.  You have to listen to that little voice inside.  I believe strongly in the mind-body connection and something told me in the beginning that the BMX was the way to go for me.  Tammy

Posts.Content: May 4, 2011 04:39PM sundermom wrote: Melissa - Hang in there!  The third AC was the absolute worst.  However, #4 was by far the easiest for me. I take an Ambien and an Ativan every night and I sleep like a baby (well, except when I had to take the steroids before the Taxol tx)!  ProudMom - Tomorrow I will be 2 weeks out from my last Taxol and my exchange is next Tuesday and then rads start the following week.  I feel like I'm running a race. The last Taxol kicked my butt.  I felt like crap for almost a week.  That was the longest I've ever felt bad with any tx, even the dreaded red devil.  The bone pain was completely exhausting! Carla - I have to admit that my eye makeup skills have greatly improved. It does seem to be getting a bit harder with the fewer and fewer eyebrow hairs that are left though.  The kit I use came with a stencil so that has been nice. Melanie-Ann - I'm not nearly as good as the extreme couponing folks, but I was impressed with my recent shopping trip.  After all the deals and coupons I ended up spending $6 at Walgreens and walking out with $6 in register rewards - so eveything I got was basically free.    Christine - I'm so tired of being bald.  It's not even a self-conscious thing at this point, but more of I'm sick and tired of wearing something on my head all of the time. I can rock the scarf, but I don't ever see myself being able to go out "topless".  LOL Funny story . . . My BFF went with me to every single chemo treatment.  In fact, I lovingly referred to her as my chemo hooker.  Well, she and I are going to see Bret Michaels (Poison lead singer) this summer.  He is notorious for wearing a bandana and cowboy hat.  Anyways . . . she says to me "We're going to have to buy doo-rags for the show".  I looked at her and what's left of my sad little eyebrows raised and I said, "In case you haven't noticed I wear a 'doo-rag' every day".  The two of us laughed until we cried.  It just goes to show you that the people that really care about us look past all of our physical qualities and love us for who we are. Tammy
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: May 10, 2011 05:16PM sundermom wrote: Betsy - I'm so happy for you!  I hope your trip goes well. UTMom - I hear you on the Nuepogen shots!  I got a Nuelasta shot (The extended release version of the same med) after each dose dense treatment.  I swear that was one of the things that me the feel the worst.  You can sleep through nausea, but you can't sleep through bone pain!  Mimidi - There are days I see the light at the end of the tunnel and days that I don't.  There were many tears shed on post-chemo days for me as those were the hardest.  I already didn't feel great so it wasn't a huge stretch to let that get in my head. I can say now (almost 3 weeks out of chemo) that my mental outlook is completely different.  One day at a time . . .   I had my exchange surgery this morning and am so happy to finally rid of those blasted cereal bowls that have been sitting in my chest for 5 months.  I'm wearing and industrial strength "push down" bra and about 5 feet of Ace wrap.  The Ace wrap can come off tomorrow so I can get a peek at the new girls.  I can tell you that they 100% better than the TE expanders.  I didn't realize how much those were pressing on my ribs!  I go on Friday for my rads sim and it seems like I'll be able to put my arms above my head with no problems.  I bought some Aquaphor and aloe vera gel in an effort to avoid skin problems. No signs of hair in fact I think I now have less than a dozen eyebrown hairs on each side now.  Ugh!  Talk about adding insult to injury . . . Tammy

Posts.Content: Dec 22, 2012 01:38PM sundermom wrote: I just posted about this on the Moving Beyond Cancer thread! I recently allowed a blood draw out of the LE arm. I had a BMX, but 32 nodes removed on the right side. However, the veins on the left side have been completely wiped out by chemo. The only time they can find a good vein is when they use local anesthesic and good to town digging around with a pediatric needle. Since the typical lab doesn't offer this service, blood draws have become a source of great anxiety for me. So, when my OBGYN mentioned that he wanted to check hormone levels I just about cried. At that point I decided to let them use the LE side. It was wonderful ...one barely perceptible needle stick. That was a week ago and I havent had a flare up yet. I won't use this side for IVs but I will be using it for all future blood draws.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2011 08:11PM - edited Sep 28, 2011 08:12PM by sundermom SStayton, Unfortunately, we share a diagnosis. I had a PET scan before my BMX and SNB and the scan showed no node involvement, and then...two positive nodes were found during surgery. Needless to say, I'm not a huge believer in the almighty PET scan :) My biopsy pathology was originally Grade 2, but that was upgraded to Grade 3 (8 out of 9 on Nottingham scale) after surgery. I did 4 rounds of dose dense AC followed by 4 rounds of dose dense Taxol. I also did rads - 33 treatments and just finished my third bottle of Tamoxifen. My onc told me that chemo typically works really well on Grade 3 cancers, so I hope that gives you some reassurance. Do you know what areas you are having radiated? I'm happy to support you in any way I can. Take care :)

Posts.Content: Apr 27, 2011 05:52PM sundermom wrote: I agree with all that has been said so far and will add that you don't want to let yourself get behind on your pain meds.  Set an alarm clock or have your DH wake you up through the night. I am 37 and had a BMX in December.  I have five children (10, 9, 7, 6 and 3) and I work as an elementary princnipal.  I was back to work in about 2 weeks.  The first week was the toughest and I spent most of my time in a dozing in a recliner.  As far as the tissue expanders go, I would say that make sure you dictate the amount that gets filled each time not your PS.  I think most PSs like to put 60cc in a each and that was way more than I could tolerate!  For me there was no hurry to get fully expanded because I was doing chemo, so slow and steady was key to making that process more manageable. Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2011 07:01PM sundermom wrote: I've been on this site since October 2010 and this is the first time I've seen this thread.  I was diagnosed in November of 2010.  I had an MRI and PET scan prior to my BMX in December 2010. Both scans showed cleans nodes.  I remember feeling so relieved.  Then . . . I woke from my BMX and I was told the SNB had come back positive.  One macro-met in node #1 and one micro-met in node #2.  My BS performed an AND and the remaining 30 nodes were clear.  I, too, have obsessed everyday after those stupid nodes!!!  I can say that as un-fun as DD AC-T chemo has been I wake up each day knowing that I have opted for the most aggressive treatment available.  I've done everything to give myself the best possible chance of beating BC.  kriskat - Will the result of the PET scan change your treatment?  If not, I'd wait for any scans until after your chemo is complete.  These scans aren't fullproof, as much as we'd like them to be. bdavis - I also had discrepency between the original ultrasound and the actual pathology from the surgery.  My onologist reassured me not to obsess about a couple of millimeters.  Smile_On - My tumor size seemed to fluctuate around my monthly cycles.  I thought it got noticeably larger right before my period.  My BS attributed this to the fact that the tumor was so strongly estrogen-receptive (>98%).  Tammy

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2011 06:24PM sundermom wrote: KG1234- I am also 37.  I had a BMX on 12/15/2010.  My tumor size was 2.2cm and the SNB revealed a macromet in the SN (5mm) and a micromet in the 2nd node.  Thirty additional nodes were removed, but were all negative for BC.  The Onco-type test did not apply in my case because I was told it was developed for node-negative patients.  Due to being node positive and my age I am being treated with dose dense AC-T.  I will also take Tamox for 5 years, probably followed by 5 yrs of AI.  Chemo is manageable.  I have five kids under the age of 11 and have continued to work full time as an elementary principal.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2011 09:11PM sundermom wrote: KG1234 - I had four drains to start and I think that last one came out at 2 weeks. The drains are definitely one of the more annoying parts in this process!  I had all of the nodes removed under my right arm so I had numbness (exactly like you described in the under arm area) and some weakness on that side for several weeks.  I'm now almost 12 weeks out have my complete range of motion back and no numbness.  I was vigilant about stretching that exercising both arms, even if it meant just pumping my arms while walking on the treadmill or crawling up the shower wall into a full stretch.  As far as a port goes my onc said he is not a big fan.  Knowing that I was only going to receive 8 treatments he recommended no port.  He had the infusion nurse come in and check out my good arm and she said I would be fine.  I had no problems with AC damaging the surrounding tissue.  Now, that being said, it does seem to be harder and harder to get blood drawn.  My veins just don't want to give it up!  We'll see how tomorrow goes.  If I have to get stuck 5 times like has happened in the past then I will be asking for a port - even if it's only for the last 3 treatments.  I have read something about asking for a "power port" so that can be used for MRIs, too.  Tammy

Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2010 09:03AM sundermom wrote: I had my consultation with the PS yesterday.  He said it would take about 3 months for the whole tissue expansion process.  He will bring me in for weekly "fills" as I can tolerate them.  Does that sound like what you all are hearing, too?  He also explained how my nipples would be reconstructed and tatooed.  I had no idea!!!  I guess the implant exchange surgery date will be dependent on whether or not I have to have chemotherapy.  The PS seemed surprised that my oncologist had not already made that decision being that I'm only 37.  However, the oncologist wants to see the results of the SNB and Oncotype testing, if applicable, before making that decision.  I had a PET scan this morning.  I prayed the entire time that the tracer wouldn't flag any other parts of my body.  I still feel like I don't know exactly what I'm up against.  Everyone is calling it Stage I right now, but I know that could change dramatically with any given test.  It's nerve-wracking!!! DH and I finished most of our Christmas shopping last weekend for our five kiddies (10, 8, 7, 5, and 3)!  It was nice to be out and about enjoying the holiday lights and decorations.  I find myself starting to lose sleep again, almost like in the beginning of this whole process, as I get closer to the surgery date.  I've had several surgery dreams and none of them were pleasant :( Good Luck to the December 1st ladies tomorrow.  All of this anxiety and waiting will soon be over for us all! Tammy

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 12:00PM sundermom wrote: 6 days out now and today I feel the best I've ever felt!  The amount in all of the drains is down by over 50% - about 10cc every 12 hours.  I have an appointment on Thursday to get the stitches removed so hopefully I'll lose a couple of drains at the same time.  I, too, received my pathology report back.  The BS had to perform a complete AND because to first two sentinal nodes came back positive.  Well . . . it turns out that only 2 of the 32 lymph nodes she removed were affected - the first two.  I find this very reassuring.  I feel like we have stopped BC from moving forward in this body!  I'll still have to have chemotherapy, but I had already prepared myself for that.  In fact, my kids keep asking, "Is your hair going to fall out today, Mommy?"  There is a great list of head covering options on the Chemotherapy Board.  I've ordered several things already - just another excuse to shop, right?  Today, for the first day since all of this started, I feel like I'm starting to heal, not just physically, but emotionally.  I (we) can do this!  I (we) are all doing this!!!

I bought some sports bras today because I plan to head back to work next week and I'm just not comfortable going braless as a principal!  LOL  I have super long hair which I plan to cut into a short bob before we return to school on Janurary 3rd.  I'm still not sure whether I'm going to wear a wig, hats or scarves, but I guess I need to get this all figured out pretty quickly.  Also, I am not getting a port put in for chemo.  This makes me a little nervous, but the oncologist had the nurse come in and look at my veins and she said I be fine.  OK  I thought I'd heard stories about chemo destroying people's veins, but maybe those were myths ")  Glad to hear the rest of you are getting along a little better each day.  Today is the first day I've woken up before 10AM and not required a nap, so I know I must be getting better :) Take Care, Tammy

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2011 06:20PM sundermom wrote: Connie, I completed 4 rounds of dose dense AC (adriamycin and cytoxan) followed by 4 rounds of dose dense Taxol earlier this year. I think doxorubicin and A are the same thing. Chemo was much easier than I ever thought it would be. There are medicines to combat almost every possible side effect. I missed very little work and the Neulasta shot kept my counts within normal levels during all of the treatments. I just finished radiation this past July and I thought that was even easier than chemo. It made me very grumpy to having to go for an appointment everyday and my skin got a little pink, but overall I found radiation to be a non-event. The unknown is scary, but please take some comfort in the fact that many women on this board will tell you that treatment is very "manageable".

My tx consists of 5 different machine positions, but I'm getting the whole breast, supra clavicle and axilla treated. I think I get zapped about 12 times with the longest being about 20 seconds. I had #12 today and it feels like I have razor burn, but no redness, peeling or swelling. I've been putting the aloe in the refrigerator and then putting it on. Oh my ...it feels so good :) I was very happy to read the information about the new Canadian study for those of us in the "gray" area for rads. My MO said MD Anderson has also recently published a paper regarding rads after BMX with patients having 1-3 positive nodes. Same conclusion ....lots fewer recurrences! Tammy
